a.name: non-agouti
a.note: Washes out the stripes of red cats and deletes them if the cat is not.

Sp.name: spotted
Sp.note: makes mackerel and blotched tabbys into spotted tabbys. Doesn't work if the tabby is ticked.

Dm.name: colorful
Dm.note: Not well documented. Here: diluted + dmdm = caramelized

R.name: uncurly
R.note: Here: long+curly = long, short+uncurly = short, else: medium

r.name: curly
r.note: In reality, there are many different versions of curly fur.

cb.name: burma points
cb.trivia: This is similar to the same as in russian rabbits-modification, where the rabbits's fur depends on its surrounding temperature.'

cs.name: siamese points
cs.note: burma + siamese makes the mink type which have aqua eyes. Siamese cats have blue ones.

c.name: albino
c.note: I don't know whether this is co-recessive or recessive to ca, but it sounds more likely that ca > c.

I.name: inhibited pigment
I.note: I + agouti -> smoked, I + not agouti -> silver

b.name: brown
b.note: dominant over b' but recessive to B.

Wp.name: deaf white
Wp.trivia: Affected cats are white, deaf and blue-eyed, the deafness is caused by missing melanin in the ears.

Ws.name: white spots
Ws.note: Co-dominant with wild-type. Heterozygot cats are 0-50% white, homozygot cats 50-100%.
Ws.trivia: Because of the less melatonin, cats with white colored ears are likely to be deaf.

wg.name: gloves or boots
wg.note: I couldn't found affections by other gens, but notation makes it sound like it is recessive.

wsal.name: salty licorice
wsal.note: Not well documented. Here, it will be recessive to all other genes and cause one of the Vitiligo options.

V.name: resistant
V.note: Not well documented. Here, vitiligo is recessive. It could be an autoimmune disorder or stress-caused.

O.name: orange
O.note: dominant, but only females have two X.
